children: Internists must accurately diagnose conditions that can cause permanent vision loss and require immediate ophthalmologic evaluation

Patients with periocular trauma and potential globe injury should undergo visual acuity assessment and anterior eye segment evaluation with either a penlight or slit lamp. Findings that suggest globe rupture include pupil deviation toward the laceration site, anterior chamber depth loss and blood collection (hyphema)

, and subconjunctival hemorrhage completely surrounding the cornea. Patients with suspected globe injury should not undergo tonometry or pupil dilation and should have an eye shield placed over the affected eye. When globe injury occurs or there is uncertainty about globe integrity, emergent referral to ophthalmology is indicated.

Chemical injury to the eyes causes decreased vision, eye pain and burning, foreign body sensation, and tearing. Examination may reveal eyelid swelling and erythema, conjunctival injection, blepharospasm, and corneal defect. Eye irrigation with normal saline or lactated Ringer solution should be initiated immediately, with emergent referral to ophthalmology.

Vision-threatening eye infections requiring immediate intravenous antibiotics and ophthalmologic evaluation include endophthalmitis (particularly bacterial infection of the aqueous and vitreous humors) and orbital cellulitis (infection of the fat and muscle cells of the orbit). Preseptal cellulitis (periorbital cellulitis) is an infection of the anterior portion of the eyelid that rarely leads to serious complications. Both conditions result in eyelid swelling, erythema, and pain, but only orbital cellulitis causes proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and pain with eye movement.
Cardinal features of conditions that cause red eye are listed in

. Assessment begins by determining unilateral or bilateral involvement; symptom duration; and the presence or absence of trauma, discharge, pain, photophobia, and visual changes. History of previous similar episodes, contact lens use, and medical history are also important to elicit. Examination should include assessment of visual acuity, pupillary size and light response, redness pattern and location, and palpation of preauricular lymph nodes.
Conjunctivitis is the most common cause of red eye and can be due to infectious or noninfectious etiologies.

Viral conjunctivitis is commonly spread through direct contact and often occurs concomitantly with upper respiratory tract infection. Adenovirus, coxsackievirus, and enterovirus are frequently implicated pathogens. Symptoms typically start in one eye before spreading bilaterally. Therapy is supportive and includes cold compresses; antibiotics are not indicated. Symptoms are usually mild and resolve within 1 to 2 weeks. Failure to improve or suspicion of herpes simplex virus infection, which frequently causes eyelid vesicles, should prompt referral to an ophthalmologist.

Bacterial conjunctivitis is highly contagious and commonly spreads through direct contact. Gram-positive bacteria are commonly implicated. Findings develop over 1 to 2 days. Cold compresses can be used for symptomatic relief. Use of topical antibacterial therapy, including trimethoprim-polymyxin B or erythromycin, is associated with earlier clinical and microbiological remission compared with placebo. Treatment may reduce transmissibility. However, 65% of patients improve within 2 to 5 days without antibiotic therapy. Therefore, withholding antibiotics can be considered for patients who are not immunocompromised, do not wear contact lenses, and do not work in health care facilities.
causes hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis, characterized by sudden onset of symptoms with rapid progression to vision loss
. Emergent ophthalmology referral, hospitalization, and both systemic and topical antimicrobials are indicated.

Allergic conjunctivitis can be seasonal or perennial and is characterized by clear watery discharge, bilateral eye pruritus, and redness and is accompanied by other allergic symptoms, including rhinorrhea. Treatment involves removing the offending agent when possible, along with use of either topical antihistamines or mast-cell inhibitors.
Suspected conjunctivitis occurring in the context of contact lens use should prompt consideration of keratitis. Contact lens use should be discontinued until redness and discharge resolve completely.
Keratitis is inflammation of the corneal epithelium and superficial stroma. It is most commonly due to bacterial infection (especially

species) in contact lens wearers but can also be caused by viral infections, such as herpes simplex virus and adenovirus. Diminished vision and severe eye discomfort with circumferential hyperemia are typical
. Bacterial keratitis requires immediate ophthalmologic evaluation.
Episcleritis is a self-limited inflammation of the episclera (layer between sclera and conjunctiva) that usually resolves within several weeks
. Treatment consists of systemic NSAIDs for symptom relief. Patients with recurrent episodes should be evaluated for underlying disease.
Scleritis is an inflammatory disorder of the sclera that causes severe pain and, unlike episcleritis, can threaten vision

. Scleritis is often associated with underlying inflammatory diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic vasculitis. Diagnosis should prompt immediate referral to an ophthalmologist; systemic glucocorticoids or immunosuppressive agents are usually required for treatment.
Uveitis is inflammation of the iris and ciliary body. It is associated with many systemic infections and inflammatory diseases (most commonly ankylosing spondylitis and reactive arthritis)
or purulent material accumulation in the anterior eye chamber may be observed. Patients with uveitis require immediate referral to an ophthalmologist.
Subconjunctival hemorrhages result from ruptured subconjunctival blood vessels due to intense coughing, vomiting, and minor trauma. They are asymptomatic and usually resolve within several weeks

Blepharitis is eyelid inflammation, which may be posterior or anterior. Posterior blepharitis involves inner eyelid inflammation near the meibomian glands. Posterior blepharitis can occur in patients with rosacea and seborrheic dermatitis. In anterior blepharitis, inflammation occurs at the eyelid bases. Eyelid colonization with staphylococcal species, contact dermatitis, and psoriasis may be involved.
Findings may include eyelid swelling, redness, and skin flaking; eyelash loss, misdirection, and crusting; and excessive tearing

. Corneal erosions and ulcerations can be seen in severe cases. Treatment of all forms of blepharitis involves warm compresses, eyelid washing and massage, and use of artificial tears. Refractory cases necessitate referral to an ophthalmologist.
Conjunctivitis is the most common cause of red eye and can have a viral, bacterial, or allergic etiology; all types are associated with ocular discharge.
Keratitis is an ocular emergency that represents inflammation of the cornea and is characterized by diminished vision and severe eye discomfort with circumferential hyperemia.
Episcleritis is a self-limited inflammation of the episclera; scleritis is a painful inflammatory disorder of the sclera that can threaten vision.
Blepharitis is eyelid inflammation; treatment involves eyelid hygiene (warm compresses, eyelid washing, and massage) and use of artificial tears.

Dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) is a multifactorial inflammatory disorder and results from abnormal eye lubrication. Normal tear film consists of an aqueous component formed by lacrimal glands, lipids produced by meibomian glands, and mucins produced by conjunctival goblet cells. Abnormalities in any component of the film can lead to dry eyes. In most cases, ocular surface inflammation additionally plays a central role. Systemic medications, such as β-blockers, antihistamines, antipsychotics, and antineoplastics, can also cause dry eye.

Symptoms are usually bilateral and include ocular pain, foreign body sensation, light sensitivity, tearing, irritation/redness, and fluctuating visual disturbance. Treatment includes using artificial tears and, occasionally, punctal occlusion or plugs; reducing inflammation, most commonly with topical cyclosporine; and treating eyelid disease with appropriate hygiene. Reduced screen time, increased fluid intake and ambient humidity, avoidance of environmental and medication triggers, and use of protective eyewear should also be recommended.
Treatment of dry eye includes artificial tears and, occasionally, punctal plugs; topical cyclosporine; warm compresses; and lifestyle changes (such as reduced screen time and increased fluid intake).

Corneal abrasions are superficial epithelial defects that result from mechanical trauma, foreign bodies, contact lens use, and chemical burns. Symptoms include severe eye pain, foreign body sensation, light sensitivity, and tearing. Fluorescein staining permits visualization of abrasions and should be performed in all patients along with visual acuity assessment. Vision loss requires immediate ophthalmology referral. Pain management (acetaminophen, NSAIDs) promotes proper healing. Topical antimicrobials are not necessary in patients who do not wear contact lenses. In contact lens wearers, however, topical antibiotics with antipseudomonal activity (ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin, gentamycin, tobramycin) should be given to prevent bacterial superinfection. Eye patches should be avoided in patients with small, uncomplicated corneal abrasions.
Corneal ulcers most often result from bacterial infections and extend deeper than abrasions, exposing the underlying stroma. Corneal ulcers warrant immediate referral to an ophthalmologist.

Cataracts (lens opacification) frequently cause glare sensitivity and vision impairment, particularly at night. Examination reveals lens opacification along with diminished or absent red reflex. Asymptomatic cataracts require no treatment. Patients with vision-impairing cataracts should be referred for phacoemulsification with intraoperative lens replacement.
Glaucoma is a group of progressive optic neuropathies characterized by atrophy of the neuroretinal rim of the optic nerve, resulting in an increased cup-to-disc ratio
. Most but not all affected patients have increased intraocular pressure (IOP). Glaucoma is the second-leading cause of blindness in the United States.
Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) accounts for more than 80% of glaucoma cases in the United States. POAG is characterized by decreased aqueous flow with a normal irido-corneal angle

. POAG is often asymptomatic until later disease stages. Peripheral visual field loss is the earliest symptom of POAG, but it frequently goes unreported and progression to central vision loss occurs in untreated patients. Once present, vision loss is permanent. Treatment focuses on decreasing IOP with surgery or medications. Topical medications used in the treatment of POAG are listed in
In angle-closure glaucoma (ACG), a narrowed irido-corneal angle obstructs aqueous flow (see

. ACG may be primary or secondary to a process such as posterior chamber hemorrhage or tumor causing irido-corneal angle closure. Symptoms can develop acutely or insidiously, depending on the rate of IOP increase. Acute symptoms include severe eye pain, headache, nausea/vomiting, and visualizing halos around lights. Eye dilation should be avoided when ACG is suspected to avoid precipitously increasing IOP. Extremely high IOPs are seen on tonometry. Acute ACG is an ocular emergency, and laser peripheral iridotomy should be performed within 1 hour of presentation. If iridotomy is delayed, IOP-lowering drops should be administrated to lower the pressure until iridotomy can be performed.
Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is characterized by decreased aqueous flow with a normal irido-corneal angle; visual field loss is often the earliest symptom of POAG.

Patients with acute-onset angle-closure glaucoma present with severe eye pain, headache, nausea/vomiting, and visualizing halos around lights; iridotomy should be performed within 1 hour of symptom presentation.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a progressive disease involving the central retina that causes painless central vision loss. Early-stage AMD is characterized by drusen (lipid deposits) and retinal pigment epithelium defects. AMD is further classified as either wet (neovascular, exudative) or dry (non-neovascular, atrophic)

. Wet AMD can progress to blindness in weeks to months, whereas dry AMD typically progresses to blindness over years to decades. Initial symptoms include distorted vision (particularly with reading), difficulty with facial recognition, and central scotoma.

Smoking is the largest modifiable risk factor for AMD, and cessation is strongly encouraged for all patients. Supplementation with vitamin C, vitamin E, β-carotene, zinc, and copper has been shown to decrease progression of AMD. In patients who continue to smoke, lutein and zeaxanthin can be used in lieu of β-carotene to avoid increasing the risk for lung cancer (see
Routine Care of the Healthy Patient
). Intravitreal injections of vascular endothelial growth factor inhibitors are a cornerstone of advanced disease treatment and may improve vision or delay deterioration.
Smoking is the largest modifiable risk factor for age-related macular degeneration.

Optic neuritis is a demyelinating inflammation of the optic nerve and is most commonly due to multiple sclerosis. It manifests as painful acute monocular vision loss that develops over a period of hours to days. Examination may reveal papillitis (see

). An afferent pupillary defect is common, as is a central scotoma on visual field testing. Diagnosis is clinical, although MRI may confirm diagnosis and reveal other lesions. First-line therapy is high-dose intravenous glucocorticoids.
Retinal detachment involves separation of the retinal neurosensory layer from underlying structures and is an ocular emergency requiring immediate referral to an ophthalmologist
. Symptoms include unilateral flashing lights and floaters. Risk factors include myopia, cataract surgery, retinal lattice degeneration and retinal breaks, and positive family history.

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) presents as sudden, painless severe monocular vision loss. Occlusion of smaller branches (branch retinal artery occlusion) leads to less profound visual field defects. CRAO is most commonly due to carotid artery atherosclerosis but can also be due to cardiogenic embolism, thrombophilia, and giant cell arteritis. Some affected patients have a history of transient episodes of painless vision loss. Fundoscopic examination may reveal retinal pallor, a “cherry red” fovea, and interrupted blood columns within retinal vessels. CRAO is an ocular emergency requiring urgent referral to an ophthalmologist.

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is usually due to primary thrombus formation, whereas branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO) is usually due to compression of a vein by adjacent arterioles. CRVO typically presents as painless, blurred monocular vision. BRVO may be asymptomatic or cause scotoma or visual field defect. Examination may reveal an afferent pupillary defect (particularly in CRVO), retinal vein congestion, retinal hemorrhage, and cotton-wool spots
. Risk factors for CRVO include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Presence of CRVO should prompt immediate referral to an ophthalmologist.
Central retinal artery occlusion is an ocular emergency that presents as sudden, painless severe monocular vision loss and is most commonly due to carotid artery atherosclerosis.
Central retinal vein occlusion typically presents as painless blurred monocular vision, whereas branch retinal vein occlusion may be asymptomatic or present with scotoma or visual field defect.

Horner syndrome is the constellation of miosis, anhidrosis, and ptosis resulting from disruption of the sympathetic fibers supplying the head. Etiologies reflect pathology affecting the course of the sympathetic nerves from the hypothalamus to the cervical sympathetic chain to the internal carotid artery and include brainstem stroke, apical lung tumor, and carotid artery dissection. Evaluation is directed toward the potential underlying cause as suggested by the patient presentation and often includes MRI of the brain and cervical spine or, when lung cancer is suspected, CT of the chest.
